messages.content:
You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Output:
{
  "citations": [
    {
      "ref_index": 38,
      "titles": [
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "A performance evaluation of federated learning algorithms",
        "Distributed machine learning: A survey",
        "Communication protocols for distributed learning",
        "Scalable federated learning systems",
        "Efficient distributed training algorithms",
        "Large-scale distributed learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]38 appears in the context of 'massively distributed networks' for federated learning, so it likely refers to foundational papers on federated learning systems, distributed training, and communication-efficient methods in distributed networks."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 5,
      "titles": [
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Ensemble methods in machine learning",
        "Random forests for classification",
        "Bootstrap methods and their application",
        "Combining multiple classifiers",
        "Large-scale machine learning systems",
        "Distributed ensemble methods",
        "Scalable classification algorithms",
        "Massive data processing techniques",
        "High-performance machine learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]5 appears in the context of 'at a large scale', suggesting it refers to papers on scaling machine learning methods, ensemble techniques, or methods that can handle large-scale data and distributed settings."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 30,
      "titles": [
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Fair machine learning: A survey",
        "Bias in machine learning systems",
        "Addressing fairness in AI systems",
        "Fair representation learning",
        "Heterogeneous data handling methods",
        "Multi-source learning algorithms",
        "Cross-domain representation learning",
        "Fair learning from diverse data",
        "Bias mitigation in heterogeneous datasets"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]30 appears in the context of 'heterogeneous data' and 'fair representation learning', indicating it likely refers to papers on heterogenous data handling, bias mitigation, and learning representations that are fair across different data distributions."
    }
  ]
}

CRITICAL: Return ONLY the JSON object. Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not use markdown formatting. Ensure all quotes and special characters are properly escaped.

IMPORTANT NOTES ON REASONING:
- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Transversal non-Clifford gates for quantum LDPC codes on sheaves

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
Sheaf theory is a well-established topic in mathematics.
Recently, chain complexes induced from sheaves have emerged as a natural framework for constructing codes
[ref]16 [ref]21  [ref]17.
For readers unfamiliar with sheaf theory,
it can be helpful to consult chapter 2 in 
to understand the motivation behind sheaves,
which are traditionally defined over topological spaces.
It is known that sheaves over topological spaces have several categorical properties
and is the right object to study in various settings. It is important to note, however, that the definition of sheaves over cellular complexes
differs somewhat from the traditional definition of sheaves over topological spaces.
Therefore, one should be careful when drawing parallels between
established results on sheaves over topological spaces and similar results for cellular complexes.
In fact, the definition of sheaves on cellular complex introduced in ,
seems more similar to the traditional definition of presheaves in some respects222
The reason the author refers to it as a sheaf is because the definition satisfies certain categorical properties.
As of my current understanding, the author may have implicitly applied certain sheafification to make the object more well-behaved.
,
and one might wonder whether it is the right object to study in the context of error correcting codes. These concerns motivate us to introduce additional conditions on sheaves over cellular complexes.
The conditions we impose have certain analogs in the traditional definition of sheaves
and could be useful for certain applications. We begin by reviewing the definition of sheaves over cellular complexes as introduced in .
To distinguish this from our definition of sheaves,
we refer to this structure as a “presheaf” with quotation marks.
A “presheaf” ℱℱ\mathcal{F} on a cellular complex X𝑋X is the following data. For each i𝑖i-cell σ∈X​(i)𝜎𝑋𝑖\sigma\in X(i),
we have a vector space over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}, ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}.
Recall that each cell corresponds to a set X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t),
and we call the elements of ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} as sections of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} over X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t). For each inclusion σ⪯τprecedes-or-equals𝜎𝜏\sigma\preceq\tau (i.e. X≥σ​(t)⊇X≥τ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜏𝑡subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t)\supseteq X_{\geq\tau}(t)),
we have a restriction map resσ,τ:ℱσ→ℱτ:subscriptres𝜎𝜏→subscriptℱ𝜎subscriptℱ𝜏\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\tau}:\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}\to\mathcal{F}_{\tau}. The data is required to satisfy the following two conditions. The map resσ,σsubscriptres𝜎𝜎\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\sigma} is the identity: resσ,σ=idℱσsubscriptres𝜎𝜎subscriptidsubscriptℱ𝜎\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\sigma}=\textnormal{id}_{\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}}. If σ⪯π⪯τprecedes-or-equals𝜎𝜋precedes-or-equals𝜏\sigma\preceq\pi\preceq\tau are inclusions,
then the restriction maps commute,
i.e. resσ,τ=resπ,τ⁡resσ,πsubscriptres𝜎𝜏subscriptres𝜋𝜏subscriptres𝜎𝜋\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\tau}=\operatorname{res}_{\pi,\tau}\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\pi}. When the context is clear,
we write |τ|_{\tau} in place of resσ,τsubscriptres𝜎𝜏\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\tau}. A useful way to think about an element in ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}
is to view it as a function defined on X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t).
In particular, given c∈ℱσ𝑐subscriptℱ𝜎c\in\mathcal{F}_{\sigma},
we can define the value of c𝑐c at τ∈X≥σ​(t)𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡\tau\in X_{\geq\sigma}(t)
as c​(τ)=resσ,τ⁡(c)𝑐𝜏subscriptres𝜎𝜏𝑐c(\tau)=\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\tau}(c).
This explains why we call the elements of ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} as sections of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} over X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t).
However, there is a caveat to this interpretation.
In particular, the map from ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} to functions on X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t) is not necessarily injective for “presheaves”.
That means that some information in ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} may be lost
when viewed as a function on X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t).
This is one reason why additional conditions are required
to guarantee desireable behaviors for “presheaves”.
As we will see, the conditions we impose
imply that the map is injective,
so that the element in ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} one-one corresponds to a function on X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t). Even though we refer to the object as a “presheaf”,
it differs from traditional presheaves over topological spaces
in several ways.
While there appears to be a dictionary between
open sets in topological spaces and
the regions X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t) for some cell σ𝜎\sigma,
this analogy has some subtleties.
For example, in topology, the union of open sets is an open set,
but the union of regions X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t) is generally not of the form X≥τ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜏𝑡X_{\geq\tau}(t).
The presents a problem: a presheaf should assign a vector space to each open set,
yet the current definition of a “presheaf” over a cellular complex
does not assign a vector space to the union of such regions.
This indicates that the definition of “presheaves” over cellular complexes
lacks some nonlocal data
compared to presheaves over topological spaces.
This is why we put the quotation marks around “presheaves”. The definition of sheaves is designed to address these two issues.
The first issue is resolved by the identity axiom,
which ensures that sections are uniquely determined by their local values.
The second issue is resolved by the gluability axiom,
which states that local sections can be glued together to form sections over larger sets.
We first review these two conditions for sheaves over topological spaces. Identity axiom: If {Ui}i∈Isubscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑖𝐼\{U_{i}\}_{i\in I} is an open cover of U𝑈U,
and c1,c2∈ℱUsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscriptℱ𝑈c_{1},c_{2}\in\mathcal{F}_{U},
and resU,Ui⁡c1=resU,Ui⁡c2subscriptres𝑈subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑐1subscriptres𝑈subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑐2\operatorname{res}_{U,U_{i}}c_{1}=\operatorname{res}_{U,U_{i}}c_{2} for all i𝑖i,
then c1=c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1}=c_{2}. Gluability axiom: If {Ui}i∈Isubscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑖𝐼\{U_{i}\}_{i\in I} is an open cover of U𝑈U, then given ci∈ℱUisubscript𝑐𝑖subscriptℱsubscript𝑈𝑖c_{i}\in\mathcal{F}_{U_{i}} for all i𝑖i,
such that resUi,Ui∩Uj⁡ci=resUj,Ui∩Uj⁡cjsubscriptressubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗subscript𝑐𝑖subscriptressubscript𝑈𝑗subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗\operatorname{res}_{U_{i},U_{i}\cap U_{j}}c_{i}=\operatorname{res}_{U_{j},U_{i}\cap U_{j}}c_{j} for all i,j𝑖𝑗i,j,
then there is some c∈ℱU𝑐subscriptℱ𝑈c\in\mathcal{F}_{U}
such that resU,Ui⁡c=cisubscriptres𝑈subscript𝑈𝑖𝑐subscript𝑐𝑖\operatorname{res}_{U,U_{i}}c=c_{i} for all i𝑖i. These two conditions can be interpreted as the exactness of the following chain complex The second map is c↦{resU,Ui⁡(c)}i∈Imaps-to𝑐subscriptsubscriptres𝑈subscript𝑈𝑖𝑐𝑖𝐼c\mapsto\{\operatorname{res}_{U,U_{i}}(c)\}_{i\in I}
and the last map is {ci}i∈I↦{ci−cj}i,j∈I,i≠jmaps-tosubscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑖𝐼subscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗formulae-sequence𝑖𝑗𝐼𝑖𝑗\{c_{i}\}_{i\in I}\mapsto\{c_{i}-c_{j}\}_{i,j\in I,i\neq j},
where we impose an ordering on the elements in I𝐼I.
Identity is exactness at ℱUsubscriptℱ𝑈\mathcal{F}_{U}
and gluability is exactness at ∏iℱUisubscriptproduct𝑖subscriptℱsubscript𝑈𝑖\prod_{i}\mathcal{F}_{U_{i}}. In the context of topological spaces,
these conditions must be satisfied by all possible open sets.
However, for cellular complexes,
the analogous notion of open sets is a bit different.
So instead we impose the following condition:
for every i𝑖i-cell σ∈X𝜎𝑋\sigma\in X with i≤t−2𝑖𝑡2i\leq t-2,
the following chain complex is exact and for i𝑖i-cell σ∈X𝜎𝑋\sigma\in X with i=t−1𝑖𝑡1i=t-1,
the following chain complex is exact We will refer to the exactness at ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} as the identity axiom on σ𝜎\sigma
and the exactness at ∏σi+1∈X≥σ​(i+1)ℱσi+1subscriptproductsubscript𝜎𝑖1subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1subscriptℱsubscript𝜎𝑖1\prod_{\sigma_{i+1}\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1)}\mathcal{F}_{\sigma_{i+1}} as the gluability axiom on σ𝜎\sigma. The conditions we impose follow closely with the definition of sheaves over topological spaces,
with the difference being that we now restrict ourselves to a specific family of “open covers”
and a particular set of intersections between the “open sets”.
It is worth noting that in the traditional setting
each intersection Ui∩Ujsubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗U_{i}\cap U_{j} corresponds to exactly two open sets Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} and Ujsubscript𝑈𝑗U_{j},
which ensures that the sections on Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} and Ujsubscript𝑈𝑗U_{j} are consistent.
Similarly, in our context, for every (i+2)𝑖2(i+2)-cell σi+2∈X≥σ​(i+2)subscript𝜎𝑖2subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖2\sigma_{i+2}\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+2),
there are exactly two (i+1)𝑖1(i+1)-cells σi+1subscript𝜎𝑖1\sigma_{i+1} such that σ⋖σi+1⋖σi+2⋖𝜎subscript𝜎𝑖1⋖subscript𝜎𝑖2\sigma\precdot\sigma_{i+1}\precdot\sigma_{i+2} (discussed near 6.1),
which guarantees that the section on the two (i+1)𝑖1(i+1)-cells are consistent.
In fact, when X𝑋X is a simplicial complex,
and we take {σi+1}σi+1∈X≥σ​(i+1)subscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖1subscript𝜎𝑖1subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1\{\sigma_{i+1}\}_{\sigma_{i+1}\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1)} as an open cover of σ𝜎\sigma,
the two expressions in Equation 50 and Equation 49
are exactly the same. We now describe an explicit characterization of ℱℱ\mathcal{F},
as a consequence of the sheaf conditions. For every cell σ∈X𝜎𝑋\sigma\in X,
the map ℱσ→ισ∏τ∈X≥σ​(t)ℱτsubscript𝜄𝜎→subscriptℱ𝜎subscriptproduct𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡subscriptℱ𝜏\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}\xrightarrow{\iota_{\sigma}}\prod_{\tau\in X_{\geq\sigma}(t)}\mathcal{F}_{\tau},
which sends c↦∏τ∈X≥σ​(t)resσ,τ⁡(c)maps-to𝑐subscriptproduct𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡subscriptres𝜎𝜏𝑐c\mapsto\prod_{\tau\in X_{\geq\sigma}(t)}\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\tau}(c),
is injective. Furthermore, the restriction map resσ,πsubscriptres𝜎𝜋\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\pi} corresponds to the restriction map on X​(t)𝑋𝑡X(t) where resX≥σ​(t),X≥π​(t)subscriptressubscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡subscript𝑋absent𝜋𝑡\operatorname{res}_{X_{\geq\sigma}(t),X_{\geq\pi}(t)} is the map that restricts the domain of the function from X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t) to X≥π​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜋𝑡X_{\geq\pi}(t). We first show the injectivity of ισsubscript𝜄𝜎\iota_{\sigma} through induction.
For σ𝜎\sigma with dimension i=t𝑖𝑡i=t, the result is straightforward.
For σ𝜎\sigma with dimension i=t−1𝑖𝑡1i=t-1,
the injectivity is implied from the identity axiom on σ𝜎\sigma. Assuming the statement holds for cells with dimension greater than i𝑖i,
we want to show that the statement also holds for σ𝜎\sigma with dimension i𝑖i.
By the identity and gluability axioms on σ𝜎\sigma,
we have where c↦{resσ,π⁡(c)}π∈X≥σ​(i+1)maps-to𝑐subscriptsubscriptres𝜎𝜋𝑐𝜋subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1c\mapsto\{\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\pi}(c)\}_{\pi\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1)}.
The condition resπ,ρ⁡(cπ)=resπ′,ρ⁡(cπ′)subscriptres𝜋𝜌subscript𝑐𝜋subscriptressuperscript𝜋′𝜌subscript𝑐superscript𝜋′\operatorname{res}_{\pi,\rho}(c_{\pi})=\operatorname{res}_{\pi^{\prime},\rho}(c_{\pi^{\prime}})
is imposed only when π⋖ρ⋖𝜋𝜌\pi\precdot\rho and π′⋖ρ⋖superscript𝜋′𝜌\pi^{\prime}\precdot\rho.
Denote the RHS as S𝑆S. To show that ισsubscript𝜄𝜎\iota_{\sigma} is injective,
we construct the inverse map im⁡(ισ)→ℱσ→imsubscript𝜄𝜎subscriptℱ𝜎\operatorname{im}(\iota_{\sigma})\to\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}.
Given h∈im⁡(ισ)⊆∏τ∈X≥σ​(t)ℱτℎimsubscript𝜄𝜎subscriptproduct𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡subscriptℱ𝜏h\in\operatorname{im}(\iota_{\sigma})\subseteq\prod_{\tau\in X_{\geq\sigma}(t)}\mathcal{F}_{\tau}.
Because h​(τ)=resπ,τ⁡(resσ,π⁡(c))ℎ𝜏subscriptres𝜋𝜏subscriptres𝜎𝜋𝑐h(\tau)=\operatorname{res}_{\pi,\tau}(\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\pi}(c)) for all τ⪰πsucceeds-or-equals𝜏𝜋\tau\succeq\pi,
we have ∏τ∈X≥π​(t)h​(τ)∈ιπ​(ℱπ)subscriptproduct𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜋𝑡ℎ𝜏subscript𝜄𝜋subscriptℱ𝜋\prod_{\tau\in X_{\geq\pi}(t)}h(\tau)\in\iota_{\pi}(\mathcal{F}_{\pi}).
By the induction hypothesis, ιπsubscript𝜄𝜋\iota_{\pi} is injective,
which allows us to define
cπ=ιπ−1​(∏τ∈X≥π​(t)h​(τ))∈ℱπsubscript𝑐𝜋superscriptsubscript𝜄𝜋1subscriptproduct𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜋𝑡ℎ𝜏subscriptℱ𝜋c_{\pi}=\iota_{\pi}^{-1}(\prod_{\tau\in X_{\geq\pi}(t)}h(\tau))\in\mathcal{F}_{\pi}
for every π∈X≥σ​(i+1)𝜋subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1\pi\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1).
It is straightforward to check that {cπ}π∈X≥σ​(i+1)∈Ssubscriptsubscript𝑐𝜋𝜋subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1𝑆\{c_{\pi}\}_{\pi\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1)}\in S.
Therefore, we can define the candidate inverse map ισ−1superscriptsubscript𝜄𝜎1\iota_{\sigma}^{-1}
as ισ−1​(h)=gσ−1​({cπ}π∈X≥σ​(i+1))superscriptsubscript𝜄𝜎1ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝜎1subscriptsubscript𝑐𝜋𝜋subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1\iota_{\sigma}^{-1}(h)=g_{\sigma}^{-1}(\{c_{\pi}\}_{\pi\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1)}).
It is straightforward to check that the composition ισ−1∘ισsuperscriptsubscript𝜄𝜎1subscript𝜄𝜎\iota_{\sigma}^{-1}\circ\iota_{\sigma}
is the identity map on ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}. The second statement about the restriction map
is a direct consequence of the presheaf condition,
resπ,τ⁡resσ,π=resσ,τsubscriptres𝜋𝜏subscriptres𝜎𝜋subscriptres𝜎𝜏\operatorname{res}_{\pi,\tau}\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\pi}=\operatorname{res}_{\sigma,\tau}
for τ∈X​(t)𝜏𝑋𝑡\tau\in X(t).
∎ Therefore, from now on,
we will ocacasionally abuse the notation
by viewing ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} as a subset of ∏τ∈X≥σ​(t)ℱτsubscriptproduct𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡subscriptℱ𝜏\prod_{\tau\in X_{\geq\sigma}(t)}\mathcal{F}_{\tau}
and interpreting elements of ℱσsubscriptℱ𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma} as functions on X≥σ​(t)subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑡X_{\geq\sigma}(t). For every cell σ∈X𝜎𝑋\sigma\in X, In particular, the sheaf ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is completely determined by
{ℱτ′}τ′∈X​(t−1)subscriptsubscriptℱsuperscript𝜏′superscript𝜏′𝑋𝑡1\{\mathcal{F}_{\tau^{\prime}}\}_{\tau^{\prime}\in X(t-1)}. We again proof by induction.
For σ𝜎\sigma with dimension i=t−1𝑖𝑡1i=t-1 or t𝑡t the statement is clearly true. Assuming the statement holds for cells with dimension greater than i𝑖i,
we want to show that the statement also holds for σ𝜎\sigma with dimension i𝑖i.
Denote the RHS of Equation 54 as Tσsubscript𝑇𝜎T_{\sigma}.
By the identity and gluability axioms on σ𝜎\sigma Denote the RHS as S𝑆S. It is clear that ℱσ⊆Tσsubscriptℱ𝜎subscript𝑇𝜎\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}\subseteq T_{\sigma},
which is a direct consequence of the presheaf condition.
What remains is to show that Tσ⊆ℱσsubscript𝑇𝜎subscriptℱ𝜎T_{\sigma}\subseteq\mathcal{F}_{\sigma}.
Given h∈Tσℎsubscript𝑇𝜎h\in T_{\sigma},
we define cπ=∏τ∈X≥π​(t)h​(τ)subscript𝑐𝜋subscriptproduct𝜏subscript𝑋absent𝜋𝑡ℎ𝜏c_{\pi}=\prod_{\tau\in X_{\geq\pi}(t)}h(\tau)
for every π∈X≥σ​(i+1)𝜋subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1\pi\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1).
It is clear that cπ∈Tπsubscript𝑐𝜋subscript𝑇𝜋c_{\pi}\in T_{\pi}.
By the induction hypothesis, Tπ=ℱπsubscript𝑇𝜋subscriptℱ𝜋T_{\pi}=\mathcal{F}_{\pi}.
Therefore, {cπ}π∈X≥σ​(i+1)∈Ssubscriptsubscript𝑐𝜋𝜋subscript𝑋absent𝜎𝑖1𝑆\{c_{\pi}\}_{\pi\in X_{\geq\sigma}(i+1)}\in S,
which implies h∈ℱσℎsubscriptℱ𝜎h\in\mathcal{F}_{\sigma},
as desired.
∎ In fact, the statements of Lemmas 6.2 and 6.3
together is equivalent to the identity and gluability axioms.
The means that we could have defined sheaves over cellular complexes
using the statements in the lemmas.

In the context of sheaf over topological spaces,
it is known that

Similarly, in our context of cellular complex,
we can adopt the same principle:
“many properties of the global code are determined by its local codes”. This characterization of sheaves allows us to define the concept of a dual sheaf ℱ⟂superscriptℱperpendicular-to\mathcal{F}^{\perp},

As we will see,

This will allow us to identify the X and Z logical operators with the cohomologies of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and ℱ⟂superscriptℱperpendicular-to\mathcal{F}^{\perp},

The only technical difference

In [ref]17,
the statement of Lemma 6.2 is assumed as part of the definition of sheaves,
and the statement of Lemma 6.3 is treated as an additional requirement specific for Tanner sheaves.
In contrast,
we argue that these two conditions probably should be included right from the beginning in the definition of sheaves over cellular complexes,
as they are closely related to the identity and gluability axioms that are central to the definition of sheaves over topological spaces. Our definition of sheaf depends on the value of t𝑡t.
In particular, we apply different conditions
for i=t−1𝑖𝑡1i=t-1 and t≤t−2𝑡𝑡2t\leq t-2.
As a result, if we take the discrete union of

and a t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}-dimensional cellular complex X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} with sheaf ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime},
the resulting structure is generally not a sheaf when t≠t′𝑡superscript𝑡′t\neq t^{\prime},
even though the discrete union of X𝑋X and X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} reamins a cellular complex.
This contrasts with the definition of sheaves in  We argue that this behavior is a feature, not a bug.
In our context,
even though we describe the objects through t𝑡t-dimensional cellular complexes,
the goal is to model t𝑡t-dimensional manifolds.
Similarly, the discrete union
of two manifolds of different dimensions is no longer a manifold.
In particular, this dependence on t𝑡t is manifest in the statement of Poincaré duality,
which we will establish in Appendix B.
